objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to develop Chemist-X, an artificial intelligence agent that automates the reaction condition optimization task in chemical synthesis using retrieval-augmented generation technology and artificial intelligence-controlled wet-lab experiment executions. The authors aim to emulate expert chemists by enabling the agent to retrieve, recommend, and validate optimal reaction conditions for chemical synthesis, including autonomous operation of laboratory equipment. The system is designed to overcome the limitations of conventional artificial intelligence models that are restricted to fixed training data and cannot generalize to new reactions.

Chemist-X interacts with the physical world through an automated robotic system, which can validate the suggested chemical reaction condition without human interventions.

knowledge_gap.answer: Traditional artificial intelligence systems for chemical synthesis are limited by their reliance on fixed training data, which restricts their ability to generalize and update knowledge when encountering new or unknown reactions, unlike human experts who can consult literature and adapt to novel problems.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Yet, traditional AI systems fall short of human experts who possess a broad spectrum of chemical knowledge and can continually update their understanding by consulting related literature when dealing with new problems. Conventional AI models, being confined to the knowledge from their training data, exhibit limited generalization ability when encountering unknown reactions.

answer: Introduction of Chemist-X, an artificial intelligence agent that fully automates reaction condition optimization in chemical synthesis using a three-phase retrieval-augmented generation framework.
Development of a novel top match slice (TMS) in-context learning strategy for efficient and accurate automatic code generation for database and literature retrieval.

Creation of a new chemical reaction fingerprint (CL-SCL fingerprint) that integrates chemistry-informed molecular graph descriptors and supervised contrastive learning with coarse yield labels for improved reaction condition recommendation.

Implementation of a general artificial intelligence-supervised computer control framework that enables autonomous operation of wet-lab equipment by replicating human interactions with graphical user interfaces.
Demonstration of end-to-end, fully autonomous chemical synthesis and validation in a real-world robotic laboratory setting.

Specifically, in our new model, we designed a novel chemical reaction fingerprint and applied it to enhance the conventional ML models. ... we apply chemistry-informed molecular graph (CIMG) ... and ... integrate supervised contrastive learning (SCL) ... replaced the noise-sensitivity numerical descriptions of reaction yields with coarse categorical yield labels.

To enhance the generalization capability of our AI agent, we designed a general computer control framework that can simulate human manipulation and learn from human-operated demonstration videos. This is achieved by utilizing the LLM’s reasoning ability, its code generation ability (based on the pyautogui Python package), and the assistance of several tools tailored to the agent: a key frame detection algorithm, a mouse-click detection algorithm, and an optical character recognition scheme.
The compelling results from wet-lab experiments demonstrate the feasibility of using LLMs to replicate human interactions with software interfaces for general equipment control.

performance_summary: Chemist-X achieved high-yield reaction condition recommendations, with all three experimental batches in wet-lab validation reaching a maximum observed yield (µ5) exceeding 90%.
In contrast, random sampling within the same chemical space resulted in a maximum observed yield (µ5) around 52%.
The CL-SCL fingerprint consistently outperformed prior reaction fingerprints (DRFP, Mordred) across different machine learning models and batch sizes in terms of maximum observed yield.
Ablation studies confirmed the necessity of both the CIMG encoder and the CL-SCL network for optimal performance.
baselines: DRFP fingerprint: A reaction fingerprint from prior studies used for reaction classification and yield prediction.
Mordred fingerprint: A molecular descriptor calculator used as a baseline for reaction encoding.
Random sampling: Random selection of reaction conditions from the full chemical space.
benchmark_datasets: Buchwald-Hartwig reaction dataset: Used for model training in benchmarking experiments.
Suzuki-Miyaura reaction dataset: Used for model testing and evaluation of generalization ability.
evaluation_metrics: Maximum observed yield (µN): The highest yield observed among the recommended reaction conditions for a given batch size, used as the primary figure of merit.
Pass rate: The percentage of successful code generations in Phase One unit tests.
Average computational resources: Number of tokens, response time, and cost for code generation strategies.
